deployment/glance/glance-api-container-p.message:
i assume you will backport it to stein as well as there also bug reported for it against stein https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1834857, that bug is specific to NFS.

Is the issue seen in non NFS cases as well? I see nova handled z flag seperately for NFS and non NFS cases.

I think :z is relabeling the directory on the host with a selinux context which allows container to do whatever with the files in it

the question is why that was needed and if it is what we want

we didn't have :z in queens or rocky and I wouldn't enable it lightly or for consistency but rather try to understand which mounts need it, why and when in the attempt to avoid its use

but this might be wrong in principle, would be nice to get some selinux to review this decision

I didn't realize someone reported this already against stein, and I do intend to backport the patch. I will update the commit message to indicate it closes both bugs.

Giulio and I discussed the question of whether the z flag is necessary even when nfs isn't involved. The nfs mount is a subdir under both nova's and glance's service dir. My position is that if the z flag isn't necessary for things to work when just a subdir is nfs, then perhaps the z flag isn't necessary at all. And in the case of glance, its service dir doesn't need to be shared with other containers.

goals/selected/train/pdf-doc-generation..message:
Do you for build and is basically readable - or builds and is perfect?

I think first priority: It builds correctly. Then iterate until perfection is reached ;)

I am fine with the current sentence. The previous version defined "respectable" as the completion criteria and it was ambiguous. I advised asettle to update it. The proposed one just requests project teams to provide some level of "readable" PDF docs and the level of "perfection" is up to individual team. It totally sounds reasonable to me.

I did not think, upon reading this, that there was any demand for perfection.  The connotation of "respectable" is that the documentation does not detract from the reputation of the project due to shabbiness of appearance, which I think also argues against an implication of a perfect standard.

It is to be build and to be basic and readable. Is that not clear? I do not wish to place the responsibility for any "perfect" guide on any team. That is not part of this scope and I do not want to change that too much more. It is up to the team to achieve "perfection" part of this goal is simply to have PDFs building and human readable.

This checks specifically for None, but what if we get an empty list here? I kinda wanna try changing this to:

In reality I don't think it's possible to not have any BDMs because even a non-volume-backed server is going to have a BDM with source_type='image' and destination_type='local'.

I wonder if this is the problem (see comment on L1822). I can't say I understand the mechanics of it, but I'm wondering if my passing source_bdms to this new method instead of using the variable as it was done before, we've somehow changed it from None to an empty list (or something of that sort), and were not hitting code that we used to hit.

Note that migrate_data.bdms should be set by the driver during pre_live_migration here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/c67057dff34a0054977ae3873d33313c0617b308/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L8882

How would that be any different from how things work now? Before we had:

source_bdms = objects.BlockDeviceMappingList.get_by_instance_uuid(
                context, instance.uuid)

and passed that to _get_instance_block_device_info, right?

Now we still get source_bdms the same way and pass them through to this new method which passes them to _get_instance_block_device_info.

So migrate_data.bdms isn't getting populated during pre_live_migration which should happen on the dest host.

I'm thinking of [1]: "Python’s default arguments are evaluated once when the function is defined, not each time the function is called" - but there's not default argument here. Like I said on IRC, more of an intuition than anything else.

[1] https://docs.python-guide.org/writing/gotchas/

We call pre_live_migration here (RPC call to the dest and get back the migrate_data that was updated by the dest host virt driver)...AND THAT IS THE PROBLEM. This overwrites the migrate_data from the function signature but that doesn't update it by reference, so we have to return this and use it to pass down to the driver.
This comment is stale since we now have NUMA-aware live migration which performs a move claim.
Right, I said NUMA-aware, implying instances with a NUMA topology.

Not entirely - only instances with NUMA topologies get a MoveClaim. If we do that allocation-style pinning that we tried but finally left out, all live migrations will get claims, and this comment can be removed.

It kinda looks like this might get partially mutated as a result of this call, rendering it useless to the caller. Which was the case before as well... but since you're documenting, it could be worth mentioning (or adding a TODO to make the interfaces cleaner).

tasks/update/create-overcloud-update-scr.message:
I still don't get why does this fail for updates and works for upgrades? Couldn't it be the differences in the dest field? For upgrades we're using the item itself for naming the script: https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-upgrade/blob/master/tasks/upgrade/create-overcloud-upgrade-scripts.yaml#L40 , while for updates we expect to have some script field for each loop item.
The second big difference I can see is that for upgrades we iterate over strings, while here we iterate over variables: https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-upgrade/blob/master/tasks/upgrade/create-overcloud-upgrade-scripts.yaml#L42-L50

Let's try to synchronize the workarounds mechanisms for both operations and re-test. If it works for upgrades, it should also for updates.

As you put it the mechanisms are totally different.  From my personal xp the workaround on upgrade have a vastly superior interface.

This patch is only a fix, so that the /inferior/ update mechanism for update *work* (currently it doesn't at all)

Then we should do a follow up patch to make them both the same and based of what we have for upgrade.

WDYT?

The other thing that needs to be clarified is the "integratal to the production of the software" bits. 
Docs is transitioning to a SIG, and frankly, docs is integral to the production of the software, but the docs team is better placed as a SIG for the reason I posted in the comment above.
Will add it in, but TBH that part of document can use some more friendly guideline. Which I plan to do it asap.

I agree with Alex that nowadays the docs is pretty much an "interested group" (maybe it's not "special", but still!) of people focusing on docs. With all the deliverables that used to span on docs going to separate teams, it doesn't really makes sense to keep them as team because they don't have "something" to deliver.

However, I believe docs still have the "responsibility" of the quality of the docs (and not only per release), which sounds opposite to a SIG.

In the two sentences above, I said both not a SIG and not a team, so what can this be? Which definition wins? Where is the line? I think this could deserve clarifications, as Alex said.

I also think this is semantics, and maybe we should be not focusing on that... But that's maybe only me.
will wait for more discussion before I put some clarification

Let me clarify -- I think documentation is an essential deliverable in any software release, and that is why at this point it is produced by project teams themselves. The "Docs SIG" does not produce documentation, it does regroup practitioners of technical writing so that they define general guidelines ensuring that OpenStack documentation, in general, is coherent and uses good standards.

I think the confusion in "Docs SIG" is not about the SIG concept (a group of people sharing common interests, not responsible for producing a part of the openstack release). The confusion is about naming "Docs" a group that is not really producing documentation. It should probably be named "Technical Writing SIG" to make it clearer that it is in charge of technical writing standards, rather than in charge of producing the actual documentation for each project…
I think we can just make clear mission statement for above concerns for Docs SIG, instead of renaming.

If we want to log this we should make sure that the event id is attached to the log. Otherwise it's usefullness will be limited. To do this I would add an optional zuul_event_id member to this class (for reference see Build class) and annotate the logger accordingly.
Regarding this log I'm not sure if we should keep it as getDirectDependentJobs can be called very often and can potentially spam the log too much.

There are more ways to signal a failed job like RETRY_LIMIT, POST_FAILURE. Think it would be safer to specifically name the results that are allowed for soft dependencies and work with this information later. As far as I can see the only state that would allow a soft dependency to run would be SKIPPED. Everything else is either failed or not finished yet.
This log will be emitted frequently for every item in every pipeline and thus can massively spam the logs. I think we should only log stuff here (and in findJobsToRun) when a state change happens.

This log line is mostly redundand to the line emitted in provisionNodes (Adding node request ... for job ...) which is emitted for every job in this list. I also think this could massively spam the logs with 'Found jobs to request []' if there are no jobs to request. The reason for this is that it's called regularly for every item in every pipeline during normal processing. So we should only log things here if we actually have to do stuff here.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo-firewall/t.message: proto is either TCP or UDP? It should never be 'ipv6'?

Indeed, only tcp or udp is incorrect. There are many other valid protocols. ipv4 and ipv6 is valid as well.

BUT, whe proto is ipv4 or ipv6 it means we want to control what to do if an ip packet is encapsulated in an ip package. (ip-in-ip). It should not control if the rule is created in ip6tables or iptables.

See:
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/6to4
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IP_in_IP

sadly we have a proto setting of ipv4, ipv6, vrrp, and gre in THT.

examples

- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/677237/21/deployment/kubernetes/kubernetes-worker-baremetal-ansible.yaml@61 
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/677237/21/deployment/keepalived/keepalived-container-puppet.yaml@78

While this doesn't make that proto setting right in any way, it is something we have to deal with for the time being.

ironic/drivers/base.py.message:
Surely this would be good for redfish, but for ipmi what would we do?

I also wonder about other drivers.

This is up to the driver to announce the LEDs it has access to via the `get_supported_leds` call.

If this management interface of some particular hardware type does not support certain `component`, it won't report the LEDs for it here and through `get_supported_leds`.
Are these list of devices? Is indicator IDs are devices? It looks to me these are devices that support 'indication' of some sort.

These are lists of opaque indicator IDs.

The model I am trying to implement here is that ironic introduces the definite kinds  of hardware components that might have indicators. These are 'system', 'chassis' and 'drive'. That allows user to ask ironic to light up the LED here or there.

Generally speaking, there may be more than one instance of each component. Drive is the most obvious example. That brings up the need for another identifier - indicator (or component) ID.

Another dimension of the same problem is that every single component instance may have more than one LED. Perhaps it's more of the OEM thing, standard Redfish does not seem to offer multiple indicators so far.

So the general case is that there can be many instances of the same component (e.g. drive), each component instance may carry many different indicators (e.g. activity, failure, service etc).

I am thinking that fixing component types but leaving component/indicator instance IDs untyped is a reasonable midground here. Then the driver could  maintain a reasonable set of self-explanatory names of the indicators. For Redfish it is likely to be just component names.

Then ironic could report:

* LED on "drive" component, ID "fujitsu-123"
* LED on "system"  component, ID "OK-TO-REMOVE"

This flexible indicator name approach suggests that the user should have a way to discover the indicators being offered.

The fallback scenario for ironic would be to operate on all indicators of the given type if the user can't discover or pick any specific indicator ID.

We have the 'Instance.numa_topology.cells[*].cpu_pinning' fields. If we can map that to a given allocation, we should be able to decide whether to transfer N VCPUs to N PCPUs or not.

 > Do we allow that?
 >
 > Or even if we don't encourage it, has it been possible?

We don't stop people doing it. You'd be getting almost no benefit from using pinning if you were doing this, but nothing in the API or elsewhere prevents it.

Mapping to a given allocation requires some kind of mapping between a device/thing here in nova land and some thing in placement land (a resource provider).

If PCPU and VCPU are modelled as a resource class of inventory with total > 1 on a generic resource provider like a compute host or a numa node, when we allocate "1" of that total, placement doesn't know which "1", only that it is one of the several available "1".

If the PCPU is modelled in placement as a nested resource, as inventory on a child NUMA node, and the NUMA node resource provider can be clearly associated with a reference in the numa_topology, then you can at least narrow down where the allocation should go.

But looking earlier in the stack that doesn't appear to be what's happening here, PCPU is not nested.

Given that, if you want to avoid arbitrarily moving all VCPU allocations to PCPU, the piece of information you have that _might_ allow you to branch one way or another is the consumer_uuid, which is the instance_uuid. Presumably the instance knows whether it is pinned or not?

When I set the cpu_dedicated_set option for a host with shared numa instance, then the inventory update will fail, but the nova-compute is still running, if stop and start the instance, the instance is going to error status. Emm..I don't think they are same thing. The case I found is the reshape failed, then continue reporting VCPU, so the shared numa instance can be schedule to this host, but this host without cpu_shared_set, so the cpusets in xml is empty which leads to the error from libvirt. We can have check when reshape if there are VCPU consuming, then refuse to reshape and stop the nova-compute.

I suspect the exact same thing will happen on stable/stein if you boot NUMA-based instances with 'vcpu_pin_set' and then change 'vcpu_pin_set' to exclude some host CPUs that were previously included.

I don't think there's anything we can do about this. I could add a startup check to ensure 'vcpu_pin_set'/'cpu_dedicated_set'/'cpu_shared_set' are correctly set given the cpuset of existing instances, but that will be very slow. Another thing we could do is just catch that particular error and suggest the user cold migrate the instance, but I'm not sure if that's possible either since we'd have to fine tune our exception handling in a way that libvirt might not support. I'm open to other ideas too

The steps as below:

* Boot shared numa instance.
* Upgrade the control plane and compute node
* Update the cpu_dedicated_set which trigger the reshape but failed
* Stop that existed shared numa instance
* Start that existed shared numa instance but failed
* Boot new shared numa instance, it is going to error status.
* Fix the cpu_dedicated_set to cpu_shared_set, then the existed shared numa instance can be started.

This seems to be begging for a service version base check. Why are you making the operators toggle this manually (and thus do another full service restart dance post upgrade)?

I'm not sure how a service version check would help us in placement land? We need to support a mixed version environment, and in that mixed version environment a "VCPU" reported by a compute node can be either (a) something that can be used by pinned and unpinned instances (a Stein compute node) or (b) something that can only be used by unpinned instances (a Train compute node). Similarly, the absence of PCPU can indicate either (a) a Stein compute node that's incapable of reporting these things or (b) a Train compute node that's configured to report only VCPU inventory. fwict, placement doesn't to provide any way to say "I want PCPUs if the resource provider is on Train else I want VCPU" in a request. You have to request one or the other and that means having a switchover point where the cloud has enough Train compute nodes to start handling requests.

Right?

We discussed this on IRC, but for posterity...

 > However, I made this comment before I had digested more of the
 > series, and I think your answer is going to be that there are
 > actually a bunch of steps involved in an upgrade now. Something
 > like:
 > 
 > 1. Upgrade controllers, restarting, leave this =False
 > 2. Upgrade computes slowly, restarting
 > 3. Atomically change all the configs on all the computes to go from
 > the old style to the new style and restart them all atomically
 > 4. Quickly set this to true on all controllers and restart
 > 
 > Right?

Yes.

 > I'm saying that process pretty much sucks and it would be good to
 > find a way to make it suck less.

Agreed.

 > Since you're adding a
 > non-workaround flag that is already deprecated, it seems like we
 > could probably use service version, either on the controller side
 > or both sides to make that work a little better.

As discussed on IRC, this wouldn't do since it will only tell us that the service on Train code, not that it's using new config options. We can't require operators update their configuration in order to upgrade. What we're going with instead is a change to how we request these things from placement, such that if we cannot find any hosts with PCPUs, we fall back to requesting VCPUs and rely on the NUMATopologyFilter to filter out hosts that actually don't have PCPUs. The patch is at [1] and the reasoning behind how it's able to work described at [2].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/681383/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/681383/5/nova/scheduler/manager.py@165

Sure, you can't ask placement for something with a conditional. This knob is intended to be that control, where you slowly upgrade all the computes to expose the new thing, and then once you're sure they do (or enough do) you flip this switch, right?

So my point was that if you make the translation activity conditional on "are all the compute nodes upgraded" then it will automatically switch to doing the translation when that thing happens.

However, I made this comment before I had digested more of the series, and I think your answer is going to be that there are actually a bunch of steps involved in an upgrade now. Something like:

 1. Upgrade controllers, restarting, leave this =False
 2. Upgrade computes slowly, restarting
 3. Atomically change all the configs on all the computes to go from the old style to the new style and restart them all atomically
 4. Quickly set this to true on all controllers and restart

Right?

I'm saying that process pretty much sucks and it would be good to find a way to make it suck less. Since you're adding a non-workaround flag that is already deprecated, it seems like we could probably use service version, either on the controller side or both sides to make that work a little better.

tacker/common/csar_utils.py.message: I have added check in conductor server init_host method. If the path doesn't exists, the conductor service will be terminated.

As I commented on patchset 5, I would like to support short notation of artifact, i.e.

  artifacts:
    <artifact_name>: <artifact_file_URI>

If short notation, we don't need to validate type of the artifact (we have to suppose it is tosca.artifacts.nfv.SwImage). Change can be done in additional patch if needed.

See TOSCA [1]  3.6.7.2.1 for short notation of artifact. And also SOL 001 [2] 6.8.3.7 describes below.

Node templates of type tosca.nodes.nfv.Vdu.Compute may contain an artifact definition of type tosca.artifacts.nfv.SwImage. There shall be a maximum number of one such artifact definition in a tosca.nodes.nfv.Vdu.Compute node template.

So, if Vdu has a artifact definition in short notation, we have no way except supposing it's type is tosca.artifacts.nfv.SwImge.

[1] https://docs.oasis-open.org/tosca/TOSCA-Simple-Profile-YAML/v1.2/os/TOSCA-Simple-Profile-YAML-v1.2-os.html#DEFN_ENTITY_ARTIFACT_DEF
[2] https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_gs/NFV-SOL/001_099/001/02.06.01_60/gs_NFV-SOL001v020601p.pdf

In case type is missing, do we need to assume it's tosca.artifacts.nfv.SwImage?
Can you please give us the reference where this is specified so that we can add a comment in the code accordingly.

Is this the correct thing to return on success?

DELETE actions in REST APIs don't usually return anything on success (esp. if the delete is asynchronous); the HTTP status of the response is enough.

Instead of returning True, do

  cherrypy.response.status = 204

edit: not needed to delete OR get info on a specific request ID

the path should just be '/api/autohold/{request_id}'

cherrypy maps requests to this pattern, if there is a match anything in brackets will be passed as named args (here, request_id) to the action method

What about something like

kubectl get statefulset --all-namespaces --no-headers | awk '{print $3}' | grep ^0$ | wc -l

?

This doesn't take into account the containers within the pod, for eg- airflow has 3 containers and we would want all of them to be running.

I have tried using various ways to get the healthy number of pods and containers within those pods but could not come up with better solution.

This should hold good for any statefulset running within kubernetes.
